17.title: Emmanuel : présentation intuitive de la vie et de la doctrine de Jesus avec les textes des quatres évangiles et des notes
17.author: par Henri Balthasar et Joseph Gillain.

18.title: "Emmanuel Guibert : Conversation"
18.author: Gilles Ciment
18.appears_in: p. 50-61 in 9e Art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 8 (Jan. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Du récit de guerre au conte littéraire, de la fantaisie enfantine à la fresque en costumes, l'oeuvre en devenir d'Emmanuel Guibert surprend et fascine d'abord par sa diversité. Ses carnets à eux seuls paraissent vouloir accueillir tous les styles, tous les motifs, toutes les techniques. Parce qu'il participe, avec une intégrité et un talent remarquables, aux multiples aventures de la bande dessinée actuelle, il était temps pour nous de saluer cet artiste sensible et accompli."

English summary (from p. 150): "Conversation. The author of La Fille du Professeur and of Le Capitaine Écarlate talks at length with Gilles Ciment, evoking his studies, his childhood books, his attraction for narration and his collaboration with the scriptwriters David B. and Joann Sfar. He also explains the different graphic styles he uses for his various projects and his use of real life sketching. He talks of his friendship with Alan Ingram Cope, to whom he wishes to devote five more volumes."

Erotic comic books, strips, etc.

30.title: Emmanuelle, Bianca and Venus in Furs
30.author: Guido Crepax.

31.heading: "Emmanuel's Wars."
31.title: "Les Guerres d'Emmanuel"
31.author: Erwin Dejasse
31.appears_in: p. 64-68 in 9e Art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 8 (Jan. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Dans la production d'Emmanuel Guibert, deux créations ont pour toile de fond la Seconde Guerre mondiale: Brune, prépublié dans L'Echo des Savanes à partir de 1991, et La Guerre d'Alan dont les premières planches paraissent dans Lapin dès 1997. Entre une fiction traitant de l'ascension d'Hitler et la relation des souvenirs d'Alan Ingram Cope, ancien soldat américain et ami de l'auteur, les similitudes se révèlent, pourtant, bien peu nombreuses."

English summary (from p. 151): "Emmanuel's Wars. Two of Emmanuel Guibert's works have the Second World War as backdrop: Brune, his first album, and La Guerre d'Alan, which he started six years later. Erwin Dejasse does a comparative study that shows how dissimilar they are and to what extent La Guerre d'Alan obtained success in opposition to the earlier work."

32.title: Emma's Sleepover Party

35.title: "Emmerich Huber"
35.author: von Eckart Sackmann
notes: Begins: "Er war in den 20er und 30er Jahren einer der innovativsten Comiczeichner in Deutschland. Sein Schaffen erstreckt sich über ein halbes Jahrhundert. Und dennoch finden sich heute kaum Hinweise zu Emmerich Huber, die das überlieferte Werk mit der Person des Zeichners verknüpfen könnten."

119.heading: Emotions in Comic Books, Strips, Etc.
119.title: "Pour une Approche Sensuelle de la Bande Dessinée"
119.author: Pascal Lefèvre; text inédit traduit de l'anglais par Thierry Groensteen
119.appears_in: p. 8-13 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 2 (Jan. 1997).
notes: English summary (from p. 136): "For a Sensual Approach to Comics: The graphic style of an artist has considerable impact, at least unconsciously, on our perception of the story. Pascal Lefèvre argues that the sensual quality of drawings should be considered an essential vector of the emotion being proposed. He suggests that a closer, more discerning look at the line, colour and internal rhythm of an image will foster true communion between the reader and the state of mind of the artist at the moment of creation."

163.heading: Emperors.
163.title: "Excalibur" p. 33-40 in Burton & Cyb 1
163.author: Antonio Segura, José Ortiz (New York : Catalan Communications, 1991)
notes: Summary: Burton makes fun of Cyb for having been scammed. Cyb has bought a treasure map that tells where King Arthur's legendary sword is to be found. Whoever pulls it from the stone is emperor of the universe. Cyb says he'll pay back Burton's half of the purchase price, so if they do find the sword it's all his, and Burton agrees. Just then they find a castle, like the map says, and follow the map to a chamber where an ancient knight in armor guards the sword. Cyb tries to pull the sword out, but can't. Burton wants to try, but Cyb won't let him, until Burton offers him everything he's got. The sword then comes out easily, and Cyb and the old knight double over laughing.

166.heading: Emperors.
166.title: "Lest We Forget!"
166.author: by Major T
166.appears_in: E. Bowen. 10 p. in Wings Comics, no. 112 (1950) ; partial rewrite of untitled Captain Wings story in Wings Comics, no. 58 (June 1945).
notes: Summary: In an air battle, Captain Wings has killed Prince Yuima-Koji, the son of the Japanese emperor. Intelligence officer Madam Dragon asks for one last chance to capture Captain Wings. Posing as an exotic dancer she captures his men while they're off-duty in Katung, and drops one of them back at the base, dead but with a letter attached. Captain Wings is instructed to exchange himself for the rest of the men. It's a trap, at a temple in the country, but Captain Wings goes anyhow. Just as the men are about to be cremated alive in Prince Yuima-Koji's plane, Griper shows up, kills Madam Dragon and blows up the temple.

169.heading: Emperors.
169.title: Mulan [videorecording]
169.author: Walt Disney Pictures ; producer, Pam Coats ; writers, Robert D
169.appears_in: San Souci & Rita Hsiao & Chris Sanders & Philip La Zebnika & Raymond Singer & Eugenia Bostwick-Singer ; directed by Tony Bancroft, Barry Cook.
notes: English, Spanish, dubbed French or dubbed Mandarin dialogue.
Originally produced as a motion picture in 1998.

Summary (from OCLC): Clever Mulan proves her worth outside of her tradition-bound society when, diguised as the male soldier, "Ping", she bravely takes her father's place in the Imperial Army. Helped by her funny guardian dragon Mushu and a lucky cricket named Cri-kee, Mulan strives to earn the respect of her fellow warriors and her courageous Captain Shang. Mulan's adventures lead to a climatic battle atop the Imperial Palace, where her family's honor and the fate of the Emperor and all of China rests in her hands.

185.title: Emmanuelle
notes: Erotic comics series by Guido Crepax, based on a novel by Emmanuelle Arsan:

Emmanuelle 1 / Guido Crepax. -- New York: Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1990. -- 79 p. : ill. ; 28 cm. -- (Eurotica) -- (The Art of Guido Crepax) -- "Not for minors." -- The album begins with an introduction by Terry Nantier, a photograph of Crepax, and a kind of sketchbook of eight sample Crepax pages. -- Erotic genre. -- Call no.: PN6767.C7E5 1990

Chapter 1: "Unicorn in Flight" 16 p. -- Summary: Emmanuelle takes the Concorde to Bangkok, and on the way has sexual adventures with two strangers.

Chapter 2: "Green Paradise" 22 p. -- Summary: In Bangkok, Emmanuelle meets a thirteen-year-old girl named Marie-Anne, who is fascinated with sexual exploration.

Chapter 3: "Of Flesh, Gods, and Roses" 19 p. -- Summary: Marie-Anne takes Emmanuelle to meet her mother, and Emmanuelle becomes interested in a woman named Bee. After playing squash and sex with Ariane, she finds Bee and takes her home, and they undress.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.

Emmanuelle 2 / Guido Crepax ; translation and lettering by Stefano Gaudiano. -- New York: Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1990. -- 77 p. : ill. ; 28 cm. -- (Eurotica) -- "Not for minors." -- Erotic genre. -- Call no.: PN6767.C7E52 1990

Chapter 1: "Bee's Love" 22 p. -- Summary: Emmanuelle and Bee make love, then Emmanuelle's husband John takes her to a party at the embassy. At the party, Marie-Anne introduces Mario to Emmanuelle, but Ariane takes her away for some intimacy, telling her that Mario is gay. They are interrupted by Marie-Anne, and Emmanuelle gets back with Mario.

Chapter 2: "Laws of Free Love" 18 p. -- Summary: Mario teaches Emmanuelle about eroticism, which he says is a human talent the "opposite of nature." He brings in an Englishman named Quentin, and the three have philosophical intercourse. The first law of eroticism is oddity, and the second is asymmetry, according to Mario.

Chapter 3: "Sam-Lo" 27 p. -- Summary: Mario and Quentin take Emmanuelle to an opium den, then Mario takes her to a temple, a "sanctuary of priapus," where a tree is hung with votive model penises. Emmanuelle performs various acts, which the monks watch with interest. Mario and Emmanuelle take a rickshaw home, then take the driver in for three-way sex.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.
